identified-content.classifier: Health Maintenance Organizations and Managed Care

abstract.p: Irving R Schwartz letter says it should be no surprise that health maintenance organizations are dropping Medicare patients from their rolls (June 3 article); cartoon

block.p: You report that more health maintenance organizations will soon pull out of Medicare, disrupting insurance coverage for hundreds of thousands of elderly people (''More H.M.O.'s Quit Medicare, Stirring Turmoil,'' front page, June 3). Is anyone really surprised?

Health maintenance organizations, regarded as the solution to America's health care cost problem, are behaving in a most predictable fashion. After all, if we set up a system whose main mission is to satisfy boards of directors and to provide acceptable profits to stockholders, how can we expect that patient concerns will enter into the consciousness of the providers?

You report that more health maintenance organizations will soon pull out of Medicare, disrupting insurance coverage for hundreds of thousands of elderly people (''More H.M.O.'s Quit Medicare, Stirring Turmoil,'' front page, June 3). Is anyone really surprised?

Health maintenance organizations, regarded as the solution to America's health care cost problem, are behaving in a most predictable fashion. After all, if we set up a system whose main mission is to satisfy boards of directors and to provide acceptable profits to stockholders, how can we expect that patient concerns will enter into the consciousness of the providers?
When will Congress come face to face with the essential need for health care as paramount among all needs?
IRVING R. SCHWARTZ, M.D. Elkins Park, Pa., June 3, 2000
